David: Sir, the officer in question, who holds his appointment by the approval of the Secretary of State, made representations to the Secretary of State in 1957 under Section 18 of Ordinance No. 43 of 1956. LEAKAGES OF EXAMINATION PAPERS
(Statement by the Minister for Education)


10.10 a.m.

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, at the December sitting of this Assembly I made a statement on the English Secondary Schools Entrance Examination leakage and the Government Chinese Senior Middle III Examination leakage and promised to make a fuller statement on the Chinese Examination leakage, the investigation of which was not completed at that time. A thorough investigation of the administrative arrangements for the setting of papers and the printing has revealed the following facts:-

    (1) The seven question papers were set by seven different persons, five of whom were in the Ministry, one in an English secondary school and one in the Teachers' Training College.

    (2) The seven question papers were given to a professor from Nanyang University for the purpose of moderation by certain professors in the University.

    (3) The seven question papers were moderated by six professors of Nanyang University, each of them dealing with only one paper with the exception of one who dealt with two papers.

    (4) On the return of the question papers from Nanyang University, the persons who set the questions made certain amendments to the questions and in one paper which went up to Nanyang University in English the questions were

Column: 1994

translated into Chinese in the Ministry. The final form of the questions was determined in my Ministry only after the questions had returned from Nanyang University, and thus the professors up at the University did not know the final form of the questions. The questions that leaked out were in their final form.

    (5) All these question papers were sent to the Government Printing Office for printing. The proofs were checked by the setters themselves and returned to the Printing Office for final printing.

    (6) The packing of the printed papers was supervised by three officials of the Ministry at the Printing Office and brought back personally by them to the Ministry.

    (7) During this period from the setting of the first questions until the delivery of the printed papers, they were kept in the custody of the Assistant Examinations Officer.

    (8) The Government Printer has accounted for all the papers printed by him either in proof or in final form.

    The revelation of the above facts should have brought about the exposure of the culprit or culprits, but unfortunately this has been made impossible by the attitude of the witnesses.

    The appeal to students and others to come forward to give information with regard to the leakage has been disappointing. Although many pupils who had been in possession of the questions had been interrogated, none of them was prepared to speak the whole truth. Invariably the final answers were either that they obtained the questions anonymously through the telephone, through the post or from collective copying in a coffee shop or at some other place. Even those who had come forward to surrender some of the questions before the examination were not prepared to give further information. They said that their object was to prove to the Government that there had been a leakage of questions so that the dishonest students would not get their qualifications through foul means. They said that

Column: 1995

their objective had been achieved and they, therefore, did not want to go further to put anybody in trouble, in face of this attitude no one can force any of them to say anything against their will but I want to take this opportunity, not to condemn the perverted sense of loyalty to friends among the Chinese school students, but to ask them to sit back and reflect whether they were doing the right thing as citizens of this country and whether the loyalty and sincerity they learned in the classics taught them to shield those who have conspired to cheat in an examination at national level and frustrate the efforts of the Government. I hope that our educationists will take note of this and see to it that our children do not misinterpret the meaning of loyalty and sincerity.

TRADE MISSION TO INDONESIA

Commerce and Industry)


    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Mr Speaker, Sir, hon. The Mission will leave on 8th March and the visit will last one week.

    The Mission will comprise about 15 members, headed by Mr K. M. Abdul Razak, Chairman of the Indian Chamber of Commerce. I am attaching two of my senior officials as observers to this Mission.

    The Mission will have the opportunity to discuss fully and frankly all matters of mutual interest to Indonesian and Singapore merchants with the object of establishing closer trade ties. KAMPONG TIONG BAHRU FIRE
(Statement by the Minister for Labour and Welfare)


10.15 a.m.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, as stated in my reply to the Member for Tiong Bahru, I wish to make a statement now on the disastrous fire which occurred on Friday, 13th February, and devastated a large section of Kampong Tiong Bahru, rendering some 5,000 persons homeless and causing considerable loss and damage to property.

    Happily only one person died although there were 58 casualties, nine of whom were admitted to hospital. Hon. Members will have this tragic event still fresh in their minds and I need not go over the harrowing details of this tragedy which has called forth the sympathy, not only of the whole of Singapore, but also from our brothers in the Federation and Brunei and sympathisers from the United Kingdom. In this account, I intend to confine myself purely to the sober statistical details of this fire, the largest Singapore has experienced, and to an account of the measures which Government has taken or intends to provide.

    In accordance with the scheme for undertaking emergency measures whenever a fire or other calamity occurs, apart from measures taken to fight the fire and provide immediate medical care and attention to the victims, the Government set up a relief centre under the control of the Social Welfare Department at the Kim Seng Road School. The Social Welfare Department staff and voluntary workers manned the relief

Column: 1997

centre day and night. Donations of food and clothing and goods immediately poured in from the ever generous public and from voluntary associations in Singapore.

    From these donations the Singapore Council of Social Services have to date distributed $154,140 in cash to the fire victims through the Social Welfare Department while that Department itself has paid out $26,060. The Singapore Council of Social Services has spent a further $10,000 on feeding, the Social Welfare Department another $2,000 on equipment, the Public Works Department have spent $12,500 on works carried out, while health services and milk were provided by the Ministry of Health.

    While these measures provided immediate relief to the victims, it was necessary to consider the no less urgent problem of their future accommodation.

    On the morning following the fire, a team from the Estates Department of the Singapore Improvement Trust, by liaison with the Social Welfare Department, obtained basic information in connection with rehousing requirements. Including late registrations and additions made subsequently, it was necessary to consider rehousing 115 single persons and 920 families amounting to approximately 4,500 persons in all. On Monday, 16th February, Government directed the Singapore Improvement Trust to provide temporary accommodation for the fire victim families at Kallang Airport Estate and to prepare schemes for the immediate redevelopment of the area devastated by the fire. On the following day, Sir, I announced the Government's decision that the victims of the Kampong Tiong Bahru fire would be accommodated free of charge for three months and that a large number of low-cost flats would be built to rehouse all the victims.

    The move of all persons living within the school premises and the majority of those who have found accommodation

Column: 1998

outside the school was completed on Thursday, 26th February. During the 13 days, from the time the Trust was first directed to take part in the operation, 779 units of accommodation were allocated and occupied by approximately 900 families and single person groups. The total move involved more than 4,000 persons. Lettings of 779 units in normal times would take some two months. The organization and effort contributed by the staff who condensed the volume of work into a few days has been possible only because of continued working by the staff on the site until late hours each day.

    Now I must come to the Government's intentions in regard to the redevelopment of the fire site itself. It is considered that only a planned redevelopment of the site with permanent housing should be carried out and that haphazard rebuilding with attap or timber barrack buildings should be strongly resisted and prevented. Government has now accordingly gazetted for acquisition the full area of the fire site itself together with additional lands around it for satisfactory redevelopment. The proposals are that the fire site should be developed by the erection of 240 two-room single-storey units and 500 two-room units in multi-storey blocks. The single-storey units will be constructed to a simple but durable structure by the use of wood wool slabs and concrete hollow blocks. Individual water supply and electricity would be laid on to each unit. The overall cost of these two-room units, including a proportion of site work, would be $2,500. Such two-room units could be let complete to larger families or be split to individual rooms for allocation to small families. The redevelopment of the higher portions of the site, having good load bearing capacity would be with seven-storey buildings containing units of almost identical plan to the single storey structures but having balcony access. Such units could again be let out complete or as two individual rooms.

Column: 1999



    It is estimated that the cost of 500 units of the two-room units in the multi-storey blocks will be approximately $5,000 each or $2,500 per single room.

    Sanction will be sought at the next sitting of this Assembly for the provision of additional monies amounting to approximately $3.3 million for this development. In the meantime, the Singapore Improvement Trust is being authorised to proceed immediately with site works in anticipation of Legislative Assembly approval.

    It is considered that, after the carrying out of the necessary site works, the first phase of the scheme resulting in the completion of the 240 single-storey units would take three months, while the remaining phases of the scheme would result in further accommodation being available by the completion of a possible 200 units in the multi-storey buildings at six to eight weeks intervals thereafter.

    I should like to end this statement by voicing the thanks of this Government and, I am sure, the victims of this fire will wish me to do so on their behalf, to all persons who worked long and devoted hours to alleviate the plight of the afflicted victims, and to the very willing co-operation and assistance rendered by all bodies and organizations, both public and private, from the City Council and the Singapore Improvement Trust to the Council of Social Services and other relief organizations. Last but not least, I must not forget the very generous public of Singapore and our friends in the Federation, Brunei and the United Kingdom whose donations and contributions and more than this, the thought behind these donations and contributions, have warmed our hearts and brought solace to the unfortunate victims.

ADOPTION OF CHILDREN
(AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

10.28 a.m.

    The Attorney-General (Mr E. P. Shanks): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    The main value of the amendment proposed lies in clauses 2 and 3 the result of which will be that married couples will be enabled to adopt and give a proper status to an illegitimate child of one or the other. There are cases where the mother of an illegitimate child marries the natural father of that child and it is desirable that some proper means should be provided for the child to be adopted jointly by the husband and wife without the undesirable fiction at present resorted to whereby the mother has formally to give up her parental rights before an adoption order can be made.

    Clause 3 of the Bill will allow for adoption in this very small class of case where the mother marries a man less than 21 years older than the child. Usually in such cases the man, married, is in fact the natural father. These two clauses will allow of these arrangements which I suggest are proper and desirable to be made.

    The fourth clause of this Bill makes a minor alteration to section 9 of the Ordinance, which provides for rules to be made. At present there are rules providing for adoption orders to be made not in open court but in Chambers. Strictly, interlocutory applications should be dealt with in open Court. This has not been the practice in the past and it is desirable that provision should be made for the existing practice of dealing with interlocutory orders in Chambers to be regularised and put completely beyond doubt.

    The final clause of the Bill adds a definition section which is now desirable so as to distinguish between fathers of legitimate children and the natural

Column: 2003

fathers of illegitimate children, and is consequential on the provision that will be made by clause 2.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time and committed to a Committee of the whole Assembly.

    Assembly immediately resolved itself into a Committee on the Bill.- [Mr Shanks].

    Bill considered in Committee; reported without amendment; read the Third time and passed.

IMMIGRATION (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

10.36 a.m.

    The Minister for Labour and Welfare (Tun Lim Yew Hock): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Sir, in the light of constitutional changes and of experience gained over the past few years in the administration of the Immigration Ordinance, 1953, it is imperative that certain amendments should be made in the law to meet changed conditions and to close the loopholes that have been discovered over a period. To this end there have been several consultations with the Federation Government at ministerial as well as official levels.

    Hon. Members are aware that since 1953 the policy on immigration has been Pan-Malayan, and I am happy to report that as a result of these consultations it will continue to be so.

    The Federation is an independent territory now and Singapore will soon have internal self-government, but despite the difference in status, the Federation Government has agreed to maintain a Pan-Malayan approach to this very important legislation. There will be no change in the freedom of movement between the two territories along the Causeway other than in the case of those citizens who are specifically prohibited by order of either Government.

Column: 2004



    The provisions incorporated in this Bill are the result of consultations referred to by me. A new Bill incorporating these amendments was passed by the Federal Legislative Council about a fortnight ago. The Federation Government is now awaiting the passing of our Bill so that the new law can be brought into operation simultaneously.

    Reference to the Explanatory Statement to the Bill will disclose the reasons for the proposed amendments.

    Clause 4, the most important clause, seeks to amend the provisions of section 7 of the Immigration Ordinance in that the right of entry is now confined to citizens of Singapore and of the Federation, and I am sure hon. Members will welcome this move. Persons other than citizens of Singapore and of the Federation will have to apply for a permit or pass in order to enter Singapore from outside Malaya. I wish to stress that this will refer to those who will be seeking entry into Malaya after the coming into force of this amendment. This amendment will not affect persons already resident in Singapore on entry permits or passes.

    Sir, in regard to those categories of persons who at present are entitled to enter by virtue of section 7 (1) (b) of the Ordinance, namely, persons in the specific employment of the Government or of the City Council, consular representatives or members of the Diplomatic Corps, and members of Her Majesty's Forces serving in Singapore, they will be covered by an Immigration (Exemption) Order which it is proposed to make if this Bill is passed. This Exemption Order will be authorised under section 55 of the Ordinance as amended. Clause 27 of the Bill seeks such an amendment to section 55 so as to empower the Minister, when he makes an Order exempting any person or class of persons from the provisions of the Immigration Ordinance, to impose conditions on such exemption. It is intended that such an Order, when made, will make it obligatory on the part of persons qualified for exemption to apply for an entry permit or pass, if the specific reason for the exemption ceases to

Column: 2005

hold good. Such persons could then be treated as if they were applying for first entry into Singapore if they wish to remain here after their diplomatic or consular status ceases, or their service with the Armed Forces or the Government or the City Council is terminated, as the case may be. The Government feels that this amendment is vitally necessary in order that when the new Exemption Order is introduced, there will be a system of control, which will enable it, in consultation with the Federation Government if need be, to have the power to refuse or to allow such persons to remain in Malaya when the reasons for exemption have ceased to be valid in their cases. The present law gives no such power once they have entered Singapore under the entitlement conferred under section 7 (1) (b) of the Ordinance. It will therefore be in the interests of Singapore to have this control in order that permission to stay here either on an entry permit or pass would be regulated by considerations of contributions which such persons would make for the economic betterment or otherwise of Singapore or of Malaya as a whole.

    Sir, Singapore now has overwhelming problems of a fast expanding population and of a totally inadequate number of employment opportunities created from time to time to absorb the large numbers of young persons coming into the employment market every year. At the same time, the Government is only too conscious of the need to attract capital and technological know-how for industrial development, and to expand and improve the productivity of existing industries, while maintaining to the full the enviable position which we have gained through our entrepot trade. It is, therefore, necessary that there should be a balance struck somewhere between the need to curtail the entry of persons seeking employment in Singapore and the necessity to have recourse to steps to invite foreign capital or experts, whether it is in the scientific, technological or professional spheres, who

Column: 2006

could contribute to Singapore's economic, social or industrial development.

    With the introduction of this control, Sir, emphasis will be placed more and more on the economic benefit of Singapore. Positive steps will have to be taken to encourage people to invest in Singapore and to protect that investment with their presence here. As an important corollary to this better system of immigration control, it is proposed that the present Immigration (Prohibition of Entry) Order, which includes the category of persons under paragraph (b) of the Schedule to the Order enabling a contract employee to be granted an entry permit if he has a contract of employment guaranteeing a salary of $500 per month for two years, should be replaced. Accordingly a new order will be issued, deleting paragraph (b) of the Schedule, as well as another category in paragraph (c) which refers to skilled artisans being allowed entry for employment in the trade or occupation if there are not sufficient skilled artisans already resident in Malaya, and if such entry is in the economic interests of Singapore, and to cover these two categories of persons by the issue of Employment Passes.
